Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Effects of Environmental Change on Fish Ecology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: Jonathan Dombrosky and Dr. Emily Lena Jones of the University of New Mexico, will research the impact of a changing environment on the incorporation of new foods into human diets. This project helps develop archaeologically visible indicators of when a food type recovered in relatively low abundance might relate to human nutritional demands. In the American Southwest, it has long been assumed that fish were unimportant in the diet of Ancestral Pueblo groups. Yet, small numbers of fish remains are consistently recovered from late prehispanic archaeological sites in New Mexico, and they are rare during earlier time periods. The end of drought conditions may have impacted how people made different decisions about the foods they ate. In addition, prehispanic fishing in desert ecosystems is of interest to both archaeologists and ecologists. Understanding more about the ecology of prehispanic fish communities will provide a new source of paleoenvironmental information in a region where fish remains are thought to be insignificant. Desert streams are of critical conservation concern given modern anthropogenic impacts and current drought forecasts. The results of this project will be of interest not only to scholars, but to agencies charged with the management of plants and animals in desert ecosystems. This research will also support the work of a young scholar earning his PhD and will provide hands-on training and funding for one undergraduate research assistant.<br/><br/>Dombrosky, under the supervision of Dr. Jones, will use theory rooted in behavioral ecology to understand how fishing might have become an optimal food-getting strategy for Ancestral Pueblo farmers. Three lines of evidence will test this question: 1) radiocarbon dates of fish bones, to establish the timing and tempo of fishing; 2) body size estimations of fishes from archaeological sites, to assess whether they were unusually large; and 3) analysis of the stable isotopic composition of fish bones recovered from these sites, to determine if fishes had more variable diets during the late prehispanic period.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Jonathan Dombrosky (co-PI) has completed research for his dissertation entitled “Effects of Environmental Change on Ancestral Pueblo Fishing in the Middle Rio Grande.” During the funding period, Jonathan has helped answer a fundamental question in human behavioral ecology: why would farmers choose to pursue a wild food resource in relatively small quantities? He has suggested, with several lines of evidence, that changing environmental conditions resulting in more stable ecological communities of animals can satisfy two food getting goals. These goals include simultaneously minimizing the risk of failed food search and maximizing caloric gain. He has demonstrated that late pre-Hispanic fish communities were likely more resistant to fishing pressure and consisted of large fishes because of wetter environmental conditions. To verify and document these patterns, Jonathan and co-authors have published two peer-reviewed articles that illustrate both methodological and theoretical advancements needed to make these claims. Further, Jonathan has worked to radiocarbon date fish remains from the late pre-Hispanic period, which will result in future, impactful archaeological research in the Rio Grande valley of New Mexico.

This project facilitated the completion of the co-PI’s dissertation, which was defended successfully with distinction on May 11, 2021. Results from 3D scanning bone specimens resulted in the completion of a publicly available 3D reference library (https://digitalrepository.unm.edu/anth_fsp/6/). This project has also supported two undergraduate students, one of which is currently pursuing her PhD at Harvard University. Finally, this work has impacted the conservation of the Middle Rio Grande region. The co-PI and PI have provided much needed evidence on fish community structure and function before Euro-American environmental impact. The results of this project have already pointed to several potential future research projects with interdisciplinary teams of researchers.


Last Modified: 06/27/2023
Modified by: Jonathan W Dombrosky
